title: What does it mean to be a refugee? - Benedetta Berti and Evelien Borgman

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated number of people around the world who have been forced to leave their homes to escape war, violence, and persecution?

options.label: A
options.text: 10 million

options.label: B
options.text: 30 million

options.label: C
options.text: 60 million

options.label: D
options.text: 100 million

multiple-choice.question: According to the UN's 1951 Convention relating to the status of refugees, what is the definition of a refugee?

options.label: A
options.text: Someone who has fled their country due to natural disasters or economic hardships.

options.label: B
options.text: Someone who is outside their country of nationality and is unable to return home due to well-founded fears of persecution.

options.label: C
options.text: Someone who has been displaced due to war and violence.

options.label: D
options.text: Someone who is seeking better economic opportunities.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between the terms "migrant" and "refugee"?

options.label: A
options.text: Migrants are people who flee their country due to conflict and violence, while refugees are people who flee their country for economic reasons.

options.label: B
options.text: Migrants are people who leave their country for reasons not related to persecution, such as searching for better economic opportunities, while refugees are people flee their country due to conflict and violence.

options.label: C
options.text: Migrants are people who have been displaced due to natural disasters, while refugees are people who have been displaced due to war and violence.

options.label: D
options.text: Migrants are people who have been forced to leave their homes due to persecution, while refugees are people who have left their country for economic reasons.

multiple-choice.question: What is the principle that prevents a nation from sending an individual to a country where their life and freedom are threatened?

options.label: A
options.text: Non-discrimination

options.label: B
options.text: Non-refoulement

options.label: C
options.text: Xenophobia

options.label: D
options.text: Racism

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the most basic obligations towards refugees, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: To provide them with a minimum standard of treatment and non-discrimination.

options.label: B
options.text: To guarantee them a minimum standard of treatment and non-discrimination.

options.label: C
options.text: To prevent them from being sent to a country where their life and freedom are threatened.

options.label: D
options.text: To permit them to enter the workforce and be fully dependent on humanitarian aid.

title: Are You A Good Listener?

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the key characteristics of a good listener?

options.label: A
options.text: They always agree with what you say.

options.label: B
options.text: They egg you on to elaborate and explore your thoughts and feelings.

options.label: C
options.text: They never ask questions.

options.label: D
options.text: They only listen when you're speaking about yourself.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it important for a good listener to urge clarification?

options.label: A
options.text: So they can agree with your opinions.

options.label: B
options.text: So they can understand the underlying issues and attitudes that are driving your thoughts and feelings.

options.label: C
options.text: So they can interrupt you and finish your sentences.

options.label: D
options.text: So they can change the subject.

multiple-choice.question: What is one way that a good listener separates themselves from others?

options.label: A
options.text: By always disagreeing with you.

options.label: B
options.text: By making you feel guilty for your opinions.

options.label: C
options.text: By making it clear that they can like you even if they disagree with you.

options.label: D
options.text: By not listening to you at all.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the benefits of being in the company of a good listener?

options.label: A
options.text: You feel anxious and uncomfortable.

options.label: B
options.text: You experience a powerful pleasure and a sense of being understood.

options.label: C
options.text: You feel like you're in competition with them.

options.label: D
options.text: You feel like you're being judged.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it important to discover the art of listening?

options.label: A
options.text: So you can learn how to speak more effectively.

options.label: B
options.text: So you can learn how to communicate your intentions and emotions clearly and honestly.

options.label: C
options.text: So you can learn how to be more critical of others.

options.label: D
options.text: So you can learn how to avoid conflict.

title: The microbial jungles all over the place (and you) - Scott Chimileski and Roberto Kolter

multiple-choice.question: What are biofilms composed of?

options.label: A
options.text: Bacteria and archaea only

options.label: B
options.text: Bacteria, archaea, algae, fungi, and protozoa

options.label: C
options.text: Bacteria, archaea, and algae

options.label: D
options.text: Fungi, protozoa, and protozoa only

multiple-choice.question: Why do microbes build complex communities in biofilms?

options.label: A
options.text: To escape predators and immune systems

options.label: B
options.text: To access a nutrient source and have safety in numbers

options.label: C
options.text: To compete with other microbes for resources

options.label: D
options.text: To live alone and avoid interactions

options.label: A
options.text: To provide a basic circulatory system

options.label: B
options.text: To shield microbes from external threats

options.label: C
options.text: To enable interactions between individual cells

options.label: D
options.text: To facilitate the division of labor

multiple-choice.question: What phenomenon occurs in soil biofilms where individual cells differentiate into specific tasks?

options.label: A
options.text: Division of labor

options.label: B
options.text: Competition for resources

options.label: C
options.text: Cooperative social behaviors

options.label: D
options.text: Predation

multiple-choice.question: What benefits do microbial communities provide to humans and other species?

options.label: A
options.text: Only competition for resources

options.label: B
options.text: Only cooperation and mutualism

options.label: C
options.text: Production of oxygen, cleanup of environmental pollution, and treatment of wastewater

options.label: D

title: Why is the US Constitution so hard to amend? - Peter Paccone

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why the U.S. Constitution is difficult to change?

options.label: A
options.text: The founders wanted to create a unified country with a strong central government.

options.label: B
options.text: The founders wanted to create a unified country with a unified government, but also wanted to ensure that the agreements couldn't be easily undone.

options.label: C
options.text: The founders wanted to create a unified country with a weak central government.

options.label: D
options.text: The founders didn't want to change the Constitution at all.

multiple-choice.question: What is the process for proposing an amendment to the U.S. Constitution?

options.label: A
options.text: A two-thirds vote of approval in both houses of Congress is required.

options.label: B
options.text: A request from two-thirds of state legislatures to call a national convention is required.

options.label: C
options.text: Both A and B are required.

options.label: D
options.text: Neither A nor B is required.

multiple-choice.question: What is the process for ratifying an amendment to the U.S. Constitution?

options.label: A
options.text: Three-quarters of all states must ratify the amendment.

options.label: B
options.text: A simple majority of all states must ratify the amendment.

options.label: C
options.text: A two-thirds majority of all states must ratify the amendment.

options.label: D
options.text: A majority of all states must ratify the amendment.

multiple-choice.question: Why has it become harder to ratify amendments to the U.S. Constitution over time?

options.label: A
options.text: The country has become more unified and less diverse.

options.label: B
options.text: The country has become more polarized and less diverse.

options.label: C
options.text: The country has become more polarized and more diverse.

options.label: D
options.text: The country has become less polarized and less diverse.

multiple-choice.question: What is one way that the U.S. Constitution has been changed over time, despite the difficulty of amending it?

options.label: A
options.text: The Supreme Court has expanded its interpretation of existing constitutional laws.

options.label: B
options.text: The Constitution has been rewritten from scratch.

options.label: C
options.text: The Constitution has been amended through a national referendum.

options.label: D
options.text: The Constitution has been abolished and replaced with a new one.

title: The Turing test: Can a computer pass for a human? - Alex Gendler

multiple-choice.question: What question did British computer scientist Alan Turing decide to disregard in favor of a simpler one, which led to the idea of the Turing test?

options.label: A
options.text: Can a computer think like a human?

options.label: B
options.text: Can a computer talk like a human?

options.label: C
options.text: Can a computer outperform a human in intelligence?

options.label: D
options.text: Can a computer learn from its mistakes?

multiple-choice.question: What was the main idea behind the Turing test, as proposed by Alan Turing in his 1950 paper "Computing Machinery and Intelligence"?

options.label: A
options.text: To measure a computer's ability to process information faster than a human.

options.label: B
options.text: To measure a computer's ability to replace a human in a conversation without being easily distinguishable.

options.label: C
options.text: To measure a computer's ability to learn from its mistakes and improve over time.

options.label: D
options.text: To measure a computer's ability to outperform a human in intelligence.

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the first program that claimed to have some success in the Turing test, which was able to mislead many people by mimicking a psychologist?

options.label: A
options.text: ELIZA

options.label: B
options.text: PARRY

options.label: C
options.text: Cleverbot

options.label: D
options.text: Eugene Goostman

multiple-choice.question: What was the main weakness of the Turing test, as highlighted by the success of early scripts like ELIZA and PARRY?

options.label: A
options.text: Humans regularly attribute intelligence to a whole range of things that are not actually intelligent.

options.label: B
options.text: The test relies too heavily on human intuition and emotion.

options.label: C
options.text: The test is too complex and difficult to administer.

options.label: D
options.text: The test is too easy and can be easily passed by computers.

multiple-choice.question: What is a limitation of modern chatbots like Cleverbot, which statistically analyze huge databases of real conversations to determine the best responses?

options.label: A
options.text: They lack a consistent personality and are unable to deal with brand new topics.

options.label: B
options.text: They are too slow and cannot process information quickly enough.

options.label: C
options.text: They are too simple and lack the underlying knowledge and intuition to parse complex conversational sentences.

options.label: D
options.text: They are too expensive and cannot be used in everyday applications.

title: Does grammar matter? - Andreea S. Calude

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between prescriptivism and descriptivism in linguistics?

options.label: A
options.text: Prescriptivism focuses on spoken language, while descriptivism focuses on written language.

options.label: B
options.text: Prescriptivism emphasizes the importance of rules, while descriptivism emphasizes variation and adaptation.

options.label: C
options.text: Prescriptivism is concerned with language standardization, while descriptivism is concerned with language variation.

options.label: D
options.text: Prescriptivism is a historical approach, while descriptivism is a modern approach.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the standard form of a language?

options.label: A
options.text: It is the only proper form of the language.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a reflection of the established grammar of a particular time period.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a set of rules that reflects the language of the people in power.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a language that is used only in formal contexts.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between spoken and written language?

options.label: A
options.text: Spoken language is more formal, while written language is more informal.

options.label: B
options.text: Spoken language is more standardized, while written language is more variable.

options.label: C
options.text: Spoken language is a separate phenomenon from writing with its own regularities and patterns.

options.label: D
options.text: Spoken language is used only in formal contexts, while written language is used only in informal contexts.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main goal of descriptivism in linguistics?

options.label: A
options.text: To establish a set of rules for language use.

options.label: B
options.text: To describe how people actually use language.

options.label: C
options.text: To track the innovations that people come up with in language use.

options.label: D
options.text: To decide how language should be used.

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between prescriptivism and descriptivism in linguistics?

options.label: A
options.text: They are mutually exclusive and cannot be used together.

options.label: B
options.text: They are complementary approaches that can be used together.

options.label: C
options.text: Prescriptivism is a subset of descriptivism.

options.label: D
options.text: Descriptivism is a subset of prescriptivism.

title: The power of the placebo effect - Emma Bryce

multiple-choice.question: What is the placebo effect?

options.label: A
options.text: A phenomenon where people's expectations of recovery trigger physiological factors that improve their symptoms.

options.label: B
options.text: A type of painkiller that has no pain-easing properties.

options.label: C
options.text: A term used to describe the power of fake drugs to improve people's symptoms.

options.label: D
options.text: A type of treatment that is proven to work.

multiple-choice.question: Why did doctors use placebos in the past?

options.label: A
options.text: To placate troubled patients.

options.label: B
options.text: To test new treatments in clinical trials.

options.label: C
options.text: To administer when proper drugs weren't available.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the benefits of using placebos in clinical trials?

options.label: A
options.text: To compare a new drug against an older version.

options.label: B
options.text: To compare a new drug against a placebo.

options.label: C
options.text: To fine-tune the trial so that the effects of the new versus the old or alternative drug can be precisely compared.

options.label: D
options.text: To give patients no treatment at all.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the reasons why the placebo effect is still not fully understood?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it's a simple phenomenon.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it's a complex phenomenon.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it's confused with other factors, like patients trying to please doctors by falsely reporting improvements.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it's not a real phenomenon.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the potential risks of relying on the placebo effect?

options.label: A
options.text: That patients may experience relief from their symptoms.

options.label: B
options.text: That patients may miss out on drugs or therapies that are proven to work.

options.label: C
options.text: That the positive effects may fade over time.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

title: 5 tips to improve your critical thinking - Samantha Agoos

multiple-choice.question: What is critical thinking, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: A way of approaching a question that allows us to make a perfect choice every time.

options.label: B
options.text: A way of approaching a question that allows us to carefully deconstruct a situation, reveal its hidden issues, and make the best decision.

options.label: C
options.text: A way of approaching a question that allows us to ignore all available options and choose an answer at random.

options.label: D
options.text: A way of approaching a question that allows us to make a decision based on how we feel.

multiple-choice.question: What is the first step in the five-step process of critical thinking, as described in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Gather your information.

options.label: B
options.text: Apply the information.

options.label: C
options.text: Formulate your question.

options.label: D
options.text: Explore other points of view.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the purpose of asking critical questions when applying information?

options.label: A
options.text: To ignore all available options and choose an answer at random.

options.label: B
options.text: To find what we're looking for and decide whether the new fad really suits our needs.

options.label: C
options.text: To ask ourselves what concepts are at work, what assumptions exist, and whether our interpretation of the information is logically sound.

options.label: D
options.text: To assume the sender is telling the truth and that we'll win any money.

multiple-choice.question: What is the fourth step in the five-step process of critical thinking, as described in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Consider the implications.

options.label: B
options.text: Explore other points of view.

options.label: C
options.text: Gather your information.

options.label: D
options.text: Apply the information.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of exploring other points of view, as described in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: To ignore the opposing viewpoints and only consider our own opinion.

options.label: B
options.text: To evaluate our own choices and make more informed decisions.

options.label: C
options.text: To assume that our own viewpoint is the only valid one.

options.label: D
options.text: To convince others to agree with our opinion.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what was the purpose of the agoge in Sparta?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: To turn a boy into a Spartan warrior through thirteen years of relentless, harsh, and often brutal training.

multiple-choice.question: What was the significance of the diamastigosis ritual in Sparta?

options.label: B
options.text: It was a test of strength and endurance for young Spartans.

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What was the role of Spartan girls in Sparta?

options.label: B
options.text: They were trained to be warriors and fight in battles.

options.label: C
options.text: They were educated in the arts, music, dance, reading, and writing, and were expected to bear strong and capable children.

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What was the significance of a Spartan's death in battle or childbirth?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: It was seen as a completion of one's duty to Sparta.

options.label: C

options.text: It was seen as a way to gain power and influence.

multiple-choice.question: What was the attitude towards bullying in Sparta?

options.text: Bullying was strictly forbidden and punished severely.

options.label: B
options.text: Bullying was encouraged as a way to toughen up the boys.

options.label: C
options.text: Bullying was not tolerated, but was seen as a minor issue.

options.label: D
options.text: Bullying was not a concern in Sparta.

title: Can wildlife adapt to climate change? - Erin Eastwood

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why scientists are seeking examples of evolutionary changes coded in species' DNA that are heritable, long-lasting, and may provide a key to their future?

options.label: A
options.text: To understand how plants and animals adapt to changing landscapes.

options.label: B
options.text: To find solutions to climate change using technological advancement.

options.label: C
options.text: To discover more species evolving in response to climate change.

options.label: D
options.text: To understand the limits of an organism's ability to change its own physiology.

multiple-choice.question: What is the reason why the tawny owl's plumage has changed from pale gray to brown in recent decades?

options.label: A
options.text: Because of a change in their diet.

options.label: B
options.text: Because of a change in their habitat.

options.label: C
options.text: Because of the less snow cover reducing opportunities for camouflage.

options.label: D
options.text: Because of a genetic mutation.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a species that has rapidly evolved to take advantage of warmer temperatures?

options.label: A
options.text: Pitcher plant mosquitoes

options.label: B
options.text: Tawny owl

options.label: C
options.text: Two spot ladybug

options.label: D
options.text: Pink salmon

multiple-choice.question: What is one way that humans can help species adapt to climate change?

options.label: A
options.text: By creating critical climate refuges.

options.label: B
options.text: By identifying and setting aside areas for species to migrate.

options.label: C
options.text: By helping mobile species move to more suitable climates.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main message of the transcript in relation to climate change and biodiversity?

options.label: A
options.text: That evolution is the only solution to climate change.

options.label: B
options.text: That humans have the power to preserve much of the planet's biodiversity.

options.label: C
options.text: That climate change is not a significant threat to biodiversity.

options.label: D
options.text: That species will have to rely on us to help them survive a changing world.

title: Why are there so many insects? - Murry Gans

options.label: B
options.text: 10 billion

options.label: C
options.text: 7 billion

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: Their impressive ability to breed

options.label: C
options.text: Their impressive ability to adapt to environments

options.label: D
options.text: Their impressive ability to survive in extreme temperatures

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the way insects make use of resources in an ecosystem?

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: Photosynthesis

options.label: C
options.text: Respiration

options.label: D
options.text: Decomposition

title: How ancient art influenced modern art - Felipe Galindo

options.label: C
options.text: Polynesian lore

title: Why do we love? A philosophical inquiry - Skye C. Cleary

multiple-choice.question: According to Plato, why do humans love?

options.label: A
options.text: To find a soulmate who will make us whole again.

options.label: B
options.text: To satisfy our base desires.

options.label: C
options.text: To escape our loneliness and suffering.

options.label: D
options.text: To procreate and perpetuate the species.

multiple-choice.question: According to Arthur Schopenhauer, what is the true purpose of romantic love?

options.label: A
options.text: To find a soulmate who will make us whole again.

options.label: B
options.text: To satisfy our base desires, but ultimately leading to suffering.

options.label: C
options.text: To escape our loneliness and suffering.

options.label: D
options.text: To enrich our lives and make us feel complete.

multiple-choice.question: According to Bertrand Russell, why do humans love?

options.label: A
options.text: Love to quench our physical and psychological desires.

options.label: B
options.text: Love to escape our loneliness and suffering.

options.label: C
options.text: Love to find a soulmate who will make us whole again.

options.label: D
options.text: Love to satisfy our base desires.

multiple-choice.question: According to the Buddha, what is the nature of romantic love?

options.label: A
options.text: A source of happiness and fulfillment.

options.label: B
options.text: A defect that leads to suffering.

options.label: C
options.text: A means to escape our loneliness and suffering.

options.label: D
options.text: A necessary step towards enlightenment.

multiple-choice.question: According to Simone de Beauvoir, what is the key to loving authentically?

options.label: A
options.text: Making love our only reason for being.

options.label: B
options.text: Loving another person to justify our existence.

options.label: C
options.text: Loving authentically, which is more like a great friendship.

options.label: D
options.text: Escaping our loneliness and suffering through love.

title: What outer space does to your body

multiple-choice.question: What happens to a person's spine in a zero-G environment?

options.label: A
options.text: It compresses and becomes shorter.

options.label: B
options.text: It elongates and becomes taller.

options.label: C
options.text: It remains the same.

options.label: D
options.text: It becomes curved.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the reasons why astronauts experience back pain in space?

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are not drinking enough water.

options.label: C
options.text: Because their spine is not used to the zero-G environment.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are not getting enough sleep.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: It remains the same.

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: Why do astronauts need to wear glasses in space?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the air is too thick.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the air is too thin.

options.label: C
options.text: Because their vision changes due to changes in intracranial pressure.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are not getting enough sleep.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the reasons why astronauts experience changes in their bodies in space?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are not eating enough food.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are not exercising enough.

options.label: C
options.text: Because their bodies are not adapted to the zero-G environment.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are not getting enough sleep.

title: History vs. Napoleon Bonaparte - Alex Gendler

multiple-choice.question: What was the main reason for the French Revolution in 1789?

options.label: A
options.text: Neighboring countries' monarchs feared they would share the fate of Louis XVI.

options.label: B
options.text: Extremism and mistrust between factions led to bloodshed.

options.label: C
options.text: Europe was thrown into chaos due to the New Republic.

options.label: D
options.text: France was attacked by neighboring empires to restore the monarchy.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what was Napoleon's height, and what was the origin of the idea that he was short?

options.label: A
options.text: Napoleon was above average height, and the idea that he was short comes from French wartime propaganda.

options.label: B
options.text: Napoleon was short, and the idea that he was short comes from British wartime propaganda.

options.label: C
options.text: Napoleon was average height, and the idea that he was short comes from British wartime propaganda.

options.label: D
options.text: Napoleon was above average height, and the idea that he was short comes from French wartime propaganda.

multiple-choice.question: What was Napoleon's main goal after taking charge of France, and how did he achieve it?

options.label: A
options.text: Napoleon's main goal was to spread democratic and liberal ideals across Europe, and he achieved it through his military conquests.

options.label: B
options.text: Napoleon's main goal was to secure peace in Europe, and he achieved it by enforcing a European-wide blockade of Britain.

options.label: C
options.text: Napoleon's main goal was to defend the young Republic from being crushed by the European monarchies, and he achieved it by overthrowing its government and seizing power himself.

options.label: D
options.text: Napoleon's main goal was to maintain stability and order in France, and he achieved it by introducing a new constitution and a legal code.

multiple-choice.question: What were the results of Napoleon's military campaigns and conquests?

options.label: A
options.text: Millions of people were saved, and the international order was strengthened.

options.label: B
options.text: Millions of people were dead, and the international order was shattered.

options.label: C
options.text: Napoleon's army was defeated, and the French Revolution was crushed.

options.label: D
options.text: Napoleon's empire was expanded, and the European continent was united.

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of Napoleon's attempts to restore his empire after being deposed and exiled?

options.label: A
options.text: He successfully restored his empire and became the ruler of Europe.

options.label: B
options.text: He failed to restore his empire and was defeated for the second and final time.

options.label: C
options.text: He was able to maintain his power and influence in Europe.

options.label: D
options.text: He was able to negotiate a peace treaty with the European powers.

title: #TEDEdChat: Redefining Leadership | Drew Dudley | Leading with Lollipops |

multiple-choice.question: Why do many people struggle to call themselves leaders?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are afraid of taking credit for their accomplishments.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they think leadership is something that one day they'll deserve, but not yet.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they don't want to be associated with changing the world.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they think leadership is only about money and power.

multiple-choice.question: What story did the speaker share to redefine leadership in a way that made them happier?

options.label: A
options.text: A story about a time when they felt like quitting university.

options.label: B
options.text: A story about a time when they made a big impact on someone's life.

options.label: C
options.text: A story about a time when they were embarrassed in front of a group of people.

options.label: D
options.text: A story about a time when they felt powerful beyond measure.

multiple-choice.question: What is a "lollipop moment" according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: A moment when someone says something or does something that makes your life worse.

options.label: B
options.text: A moment when someone says something or does something that makes your life better.

options.label: C
options.text: A moment when you feel powerful beyond measure.

options.label: D
options.text: A moment when you feel inadequate.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's call to action today?

options.label: A
options.text: To redefine leadership as being about changing the world.

options.label: B
options.text: To get over the fear of how extraordinarily powerful we can be in each other's lives.

options.label: C
options.text: To value the impact we can have on each other's lives more than money and power.

options.label: D
options.text: To focus on creating more lollipop moments.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the significance of one person changing their understanding of the world?

options.label: A
options.text: It only changes that one person's understanding.

options.label: B
options.text: It changes the understanding of everyone in the person knows.

options.label: C
options.text: It changes the whole thing - one person's understanding of what they're capable of, how much people care about them, and how powerful an agent for change they can be.

options.label: D
options.text: It has no impact on the world at all.

title: The beneficial bacteria that make delicious food - Erez Garty

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of yeast in bread-making?

options.label: A
options.text: To produce ethanol and create a sour taste.

options.label: B
options.text: To break down carbohydrates and produce carbon dioxide gas.

options.label: C
options.text: To consume oxygen and produce water.

options.label: D
options.text: To add flavor and texture to bread.

multiple-choice.question: What is the process called when yeast consumes sugar using fermentation, the anaerobic pathway?

options.label: A
options.text: Aerobic pathway

options.label: B
options.text: Fermentation

options.label: C
options.text: Respiration

options.label: D
options.text: Photosynthesis

multiple-choice.question: What is responsible for the characteristic holes in Swiss cheese?

options.label: A
options.text: Bacteria that emit carbon dioxide

options.label: B
options.text: Mold that grows on the cheese

options.label: C
options.text: Yeast that consumes sugar

options.label: D
options.text: Enzymes that break down lactose

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the carbon dioxide produced during fermentation in wine-making?

options.label: A
options.text: It is trapped in the bottle and creates a fizzy drink.

options.label: B
options.text: It is released through a vent and evaporates.

options.label: C
options.text: It is converted into ethanol.

options.label: D
options.text: It is absorbed by the yeast.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of bacteria in cheese-making?

options.label: A
options.text: To add flavor and texture to the cheese.

options.label: B
options.text: To break down lactose and produce lactic acid.

options.label: C
options.text: To consume oxygen and produce water.

options.label: D
options.text: To create a sour taste in the cheese.
